results.title: Woodcraftsman: Stephen Hogbin
results.creator_credit: Peter Drummond and Craft Association of Australia
results.brief_description: Canadian Stephen Hogbin, internationally acclaimed woodcraftsman, came to Australia for one year as craftsman in residence at the State College of Victoria, Melbourne. In Noojee State Forest, where the college camp is situated, Hogbin discovers the exciting possibilities of Australian timber. He communicates to students his enthusiasm for the use of wood in crafting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Drummond and Craft Association of Australia

results.title: Woodbridge District School (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Timothy Read, Chris Noonan and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Place Where Books Are Kept”.
This film shows a media-mobile van visiting a school. The crew on the van is shown instructing the staff of the school in a range of audio-visual activities. Some examples of software are shown and various suggestions are given as to their use within the curricula. Suitable for tertiary level and teachers.

results.title: Wood joints
results.creator_credit: Joe Jayward, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description: Precise camerawork shows clearly how the end butt joint is made, how to make a rabbet joint, how a dado joint is formed, and the difference between the dado joint and the groove joint. Also demonstrates the technique of using dowels to add strength to a joint and how to make a lap joint.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joe Jayward, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.description: Precise camerawork shows clearly how the end butt joint is made, how to make a rabbet joint, how a dado joint is formed, and the difference between the dado joint and the groove joint. Also demonstrates the technique of using dowels to add strength to a joint and how to make a lap joint.

results.title: Wood Finishing
results.brief_description: Frank Klausz in this videos demonstrates the following skills: how to use a smoothing plane, a scraper and sandpaper; how to choose among oil, alcohol and water stains; how to apply tung oil or spar varnish; how to spray Lacquer; and how to French polish your work to an exquisitely glossy finish.

results.title: Wood ducks and tyre-kickers
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. In this final program, Hughes assesses the commercial and social backgrounds against which Australian art operates and looks at a government sponsored exhibition of 10 artists in Paris in 1974.

results.title: Wood
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Explains the structure of wood and the manufacture of plywood, hardboard, particle-board, pulp and paper. Shows milling, seasoning and preservation techniques and the development of planatations.

results.title: Wonderstruck
results.brief_description: The story of a young boy in the Midwest is told simultaneously with a tale about a young girl in New York from fifty years ago as they both seek the same mysterious connection.

constellations_other.name: Making films in black and white
constellations_other.description: Oscar-winner Sandy Powell crafted Abigail's (Emma Stone) costume in The Favourite to represent her ascension in the royal household of Queen Anne by utilising black and white.

results.title: Wonders sacred and mysterious
results.creator_credit: Marianne Gammon and Reader's Digest Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great wonders of the world”.
Monuments of astonishing beauty and power such as Stonehenge, The Great Pyramids at Giza, Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Borobudur in Java, St Peter’s Basilica in the Vatican City, and the Taj Mahal in Agra are all supreme examples of the human need to try and explain some of the mysteries of life, and the subject of this fascinating Reader’s Digest documentary.
